textDisplay:
Changing where power comes from is going to be expensive. Whether you have to build high voltage lines from where the wind is to where the people are or you have to reinforce local distribution lines to handle the backflow from home solar, it costs money.
Aluminum conductors, power poles, and line crews cost money. You can't fundamentally change how power generation works without changing how power distribution and transmission works. Most customers don't want to foot that bill.

textDisplay:
The biggest issue with "green energy." hear me out. Storage, producing green energy only works at key times during the day. Most of the time it is not all being utilized. What happens to it, nothing. The biggest issue is that currently no ways to facilitate the storage of the energy. For use when it is needed.

Want some examples?
1. We will start with Spain, during the Obama era saying we need to move to renewables like Spain. The Spanish government itself came out not recommending it. For this exact issue. They had brown outs, from the fact it wasn't a reliable source of energy.

2. Currently Germany has some of the most, "renewable" energy sources. The issue they run into is that which I mention. Being that when it is needed and not producing energy. They have to pay a substantial amount for the energy that is needed. You see rises in energy costs up 40-50%..

textDisplay: It’s like this in many countries. Northern part of Germany, for example, pays Denmark to take their power when it’s windy, because Germany doesn’t allow power companies to shut off wind turbines, while Denmark does. When there is extra wind in the region, Denmark shuts down many wind turbines, if they produce too much for other countries to buy, and gets money from Germany to take their power. This is because Germany’s infrastructure doesn’t allow the wind power from northern German to be transported to the lower parts of the country.
textOriginal: It’s like this in many countries. Northern part of Germany, for example, pays Denmark to take their power when it’s windy, because Germany doesn’t allow power companies to shut off wind turbines, while Denmark does. When there is extra wind in the region, Denmark shuts down many wind turbines, if they produce too much for other countries to buy, and gets money from Germany to take their power. This is because Germany’s infrastructure doesn’t allow the wind power from northern German to be transported to the lower parts of the country.

There is solution u didn't mention. We can nowadays create backbone power grid of DC powerlines that are using superconductivity. It maight seems surreal at first glance. But aren't we arleady moving tons on pipes for gas, petrol, oil, hot watter etc etc. If we manage to properly insulate high preassure pipes with liquid nitrogen, we can just put this pipes under high voltage lines and put on them relativly low voltage suited for DC/AC converters for MV voltages.
Yes there ll be need for expensive DC/AC converters that ll lose power due to transition. Yes ll have to put a lot of power and efford into maintance this lines.
But in exchange we wuld get much more capacity on this type of system for today's needs we can assume, that amount that a single line can carry is almost infinite. We don't have to worry on reactive power losses since it does not exist. I assume that voltages wuld be "low", so ll be leakage current. There ll be no EMF radiation for most of the time (only high spikes in current ll generate spikes in EMF), not like it is much of a threat but is is nicer if we dont have it for variuous of reasons. We don't have to mix the voltages since we can just put almost any current trought it. And last but not least we dont have to have expensive synchronization procedures and equipment, if polarity and voltgae matches requirments u are good to go either for putting energy or reciving it.

textDisplay:
Wind turbines and Solar will not run our society. It is simply not viable even with the changes Vox proposes in this video.
Wind and solar are horrendously damaging to the environment because they take up so much room. Large swaths of land have to be cleared and processed to support these mega farms.
The power is unreliable, meaning we need huge storage farms, which will take up more land and resources, or a back up plant, which is what they use now, which is Natural gas.
Nuclear power is the only way we can decarbonize. Small modular reactors are nimble enough to ramp up power production at peak times and take up only a fraction of the land that a wind or solar farm would. High temperature gas reactors can be used in desalination and hydrogen production, as well as heat intensive processes that otherwise would be inefficient to run off of a wind and solar based grid.

The power is unreliable, meaning we need huge storage farms, which will take up more land and resources, or a back up plant, which is what they use now, which is Natural gas. 
Nuclear power is the only way we can decarbonize. Small modular reactors are nimble enough to ramp up power production at peak times and take up only a fraction of the land that a wind or solar farm would. High temperature gas reactors can be used in desalination and hydrogen production, as well as heat intensive processes that otherwise would be inefficient to run off of a wind and solar based grid.

textDisplay:
However, the voltage cannot be increased infinitely in order to avoid current losses. Somewhere at 350,000 volts AC, above that the air no longer insulates enough. DC lines can carry about 450,000 volts. But for this the alternating voltage has to be transformed and rectified, in the end it has to become AC again so that a transformer fits again.
But DC voltage lines can help with problems with the mains frequency because they are controllable. DC land lines are rare, but necessary in the sea. AC cables in the sea have high losses.

In Germany there was an AC-DC-AC coupling because the Eastern European grid frequency fluctuated. Today the problems have been resolved and the coupling system dismantled. The knowledge is now used for a DC long-distance line: +/- 450,000 volts!
textOriginal:
However, the voltage cannot be increased infinitely in order to avoid current losses. Somewhere at 350,000 volts AC, above that the air no longer insulates enough. DC lines can carry about 450,000 volts. But for this the alternating voltage has to be transformed and rectified, in the end it has to become AC again so that a transformer fits again.
But DC voltage lines can help with problems with the mains frequency because they are controllable. DC land lines are rare, but necessary in the sea. AC cables in the sea have high losses.

In Germany there was an AC-DC-AC coupling because the Eastern European grid frequency fluctuated. Today the problems have been resolved and the coupling system dismantled. The knowledge is now used for a DC long-distance line: +/- 450,000 volts!

textDisplay:
Yes, we are not ready. The transmission lines are owned by private companies and public utilities. They make money by chaging a transmission fee. They do not build lines in hopes of transmitting electricity. Going green will not happen unless the energy can be stored. The wind stops blowing and the sun quits shining. When this happens gas fired plants need to take over immediately. They need to be hot and ready to swich on otherwise the grid will go black and you don’t want to experiance a black start without real generators. It is like starting a camp fire with two sticks and no instruction manual. The grid is not designed for a black start and no one has any experiance in doing it.

With that said, electricity has to be made when it is wanted. The wind blowing at 2 am is mostly useless and could be converted into hydrogen or compressed air for later generation. Why not batteries? You need them for your cars that will run out of ekectricity on the freeway during a 5:00 o’clock rush hour running the AC on a hot Texas evening. Good luck getting the freeway restarted with thousands of dead car batteries and no extention cords.

textDisplay:
The problem with upscaling the capacity is that there still will be a maximum capacity ,just a higher one. Instead, we could solve our energy storage problem ánd transportation problem by making use of hydrogen cells. This will take away the unreliability of certain sustainable energy sources by storing then when they do produce and make use of it when required. This of course causes for a loss in efficiency as compared to using solely electric, though upscaling the whole business or even exporting it to other countries/states would be made possible.

Make sure there is a slight overproduction compared to consumption. And take away the unreliability with storage (eg. oil terminal/tanks etc). Also note hydrogen has an energy density of approximately 120 MJ/kg, almost three times more than diesel or gasoline. Downside of course is when used on small scale, cars etc, it only has a 60% efficiency, wheras larger facilities would operate at a much higher efficiency of course.

textDisplay: It's far easier to put solar on roofs and batteries in homes than build large scale generation and transmission. If the proportion of homes and businesses that could make 50% of their daily power and store some of it for use later was increased, it would proportionally decrease pressure on the grid and make the entire system more resilient in the event of failure. I can produce up to 75kWh / day via my solar and I can store up to 27kWh via my batteries. Outages happen about once a month ....and we don't even notice.

textDisplay: I'm surprised they didn't talk about the economics of buying and selling electricity. The best way to get electricity from renewable energy from the producing areas to where people live is by making it as cheap and easy to exchange as possible. That's how solar electricity from Arizona can provide power to Illinois when it's not windy and vice versa when it's cloudy in Arizona. However that means states can't make money when they export the electricity, which hurts their economy. Pretty big factor in why the US isn't ready for clean energy.
textOriginal: I'm surprised they didn't talk about the economics of buying and selling electricity. The best way to get electricity from renewable energy from the producing areas to where people live is by making it as cheap and easy to exchange as possible. That's how solar electricity from Arizona can provide power to Illinois when it's not windy and vice versa when it's cloudy in Arizona. However that means states can't make money when they export the electricity, which hurts their economy. Pretty big factor in why the US isn't ready for clean energy.

textDisplay:
Transporting energy from renewable sources via powerlines is probably the most inefficient way to tackle this issue. Because wind and solar fluctuate so much in their output, the potential energy output varies just as much. Putting all this energy on one grid requires a huge capacity for peak moments. Moreover, a significant amount of energy would have to be stored in batteries for the downtime, and batteries are notoriously expensive in resources.

A better way to tackle the issue is to convert the wind and solar energy locally to some kind of carrier. A good example would be hydrogen, which can be produced from water in large quantities with the electricity gained from solar or wind power. The liquid hydrogen can then be transported to wherever it is needed, either by road or even by pipeline if demand is high and consistent enough. The hydrogen can easily be stored and used to power cities. This also make the US much more flexible in terms of emergencies, like the one in Texas last February. Grids can stay disconnected and localized, with only the stored hydrogen needing to be transported. This makes high voltage power lines almost obsolete, saving huge amounts of resources.
textOriginal:

Because wind and solar fluctuate so much in their output, the potential energy output varies just as much. Putting all this energy on one grid requires a huge capacity for peak moments. Moreover, a significant amount of energy would have to be stored in batteries for the downtime, and batteries are notoriously expensive in resources. 

A better way to tackle the issue is to convert the wind and solar energy locally to some kind of carrier. A good example would be hydrogen, which can be produced from water in large quantities with the electricity gained from solar or wind power. The liquid hydrogen can then be transported to wherever it is needed, either by road or even by pipeline if demand is high and consistent enough. The hydrogen can easily be stored and used to power cities. This also make the US much more flexible in terms of emergencies, like the one in Texas last February. textDisplay: This is all so very very wrong.  What we need to do is get rid of the grid.  If we do solar right, we don't need it.  Put the panels where you need the power, on your roof.  Store it in batteries so you have it all night as well.  No more power failures that black out a whole city, they'll just take out one house here and there.  No more wildfires caused by power lines.  We'll still move electricity around, but for hundreds of feet, not thousands of miles.  Your electric power equipment will be your responsibility, just like HVAC is now.  We have 13 panels and a Tesla Powerwall 2, and we've been over 99% self powered for a month.  More people will be able to afford solar when the market is flooded with cheap used panels from bankrupt solar farms.

textDisplay: The task of building a  green energy network will be monumental.  The best solar and wind resources are mostly in areas with low population densities.  For example Arizona has good potential for solar energy.  North Dakota has  excellent wind energy resources.  But these states are far from where most energy is consumed.  We need an energy New Deal no less monumental than the actual New Deal initiated by Franklin Roosevelt during the Great Depression.  Politics may be an obstacle as many if not most of the ideal areas suitable for solar and wind are in red states where many people are skeptical of "Big Government" and environmental initiatives.  But I think where there is a will there is a way and this can be done.

textDisplay:
4:25 - Incorrect. The thicker the cable, the more current it can handle, not the more voltage.

5:22 - Also incorrect. Arizona and Chicago are not on the same power grid, so you cannot transmit power between those two locations. Arizona is on the Western Interconnection, while Chicago is on the Eastern one.
textOriginal:
4:25 - Incorrect.  The thicker the cable, the more _current_ it can handle, not the more voltage.

5:22 - Also incorrect.  Arizona and Chicago are not on the same power grid, so you cannot transmit power between those two locations.  Arizona is on the Western Interconnection, while Chicago is on the Eastern one.

textDisplay:
Seems to me like building massive new power grids that have all kinds of environmental impact on their own is a bit counterintuitive. Why not shift from this 19th/20th century thinking & start adapting every existing & new structure built to act as its own independent energy harvesting cell. Solar roof tiles, residential scale wind turbines, etc. There are actually a lot of ancient, pre AC architectural designs we can modernize & start using again. We stopped using them because in many ways we entered an age of ignorance driven by consumerism, that we're only now struggling to climb out of.

Things can be built to be sustainable & affordable. It had to be out of necessity in the old world. Somewhere on our march from the fall of the Roman empire to the rise of a global, industrial empire, we lost site of that.

Things *can* be built to be sustainable & affordable. It had to be out of necessity in the old world. Somewhere on our march from the fall of the Roman empire to the rise of a global, industrial empire, we lost site of that.

textDisplay:
The documentary overlooks a key energy alternative, the one which actually makes the 2032 goals viable: hydrogen.
Hydrogen will come from solar power plants in Western states including from the California near-coastal desert and semi-desert. Hence, a large part of the new US power grid to be built or rebuilt isn't an electric power grid at all. Will be rather hydrogen distribution grids and logistics networks. As a consequence, the Princeton map of eligible renewables production areas you use needs redrawing. And so does your narrative. Incidentally this is why most of us will still have the option of cooking with electric or gas in 2032 and beyond. H2 solar energy storage is the missing link in your story and will do the trick - in tandem with all other hydro and wind generation that might be possible in the mid west states.

textDisplay:
Federal laws need to be created governing those monopolies we call public utilities to make sure they pay at least what they charge consumers.
Yes, if you are buying power for 13 cents/KWH then if you produce 1 KWH the utility should pay you at a minimum 13 cents.
With rooftop power the need for more infrastructure is a false one, you are providing power to you neighbors or using it yourself, it actually reduces load on the grid because you have many small producers working very locally.

The role of the public utility must change from the monopoly that provides all your power to a provider that wheels power on the grid and regulates voltage and current on the grid as needed. Demand will be at night and on darker days as well as a few months in winter when production is low, some of this low production can be offset by wind power that by it's nature and cost is more commercial.

I have done rooftop solar since 2012, I am totally delighted with it's result and I got in with a well compensating 15 year contract. I know if such a program was widely available today many people would go rooftop solar.
I own a 9 KW 3 array grid tie system and make enough money to nearly negate by total annual gas and electric bill, it works if well designed and properly compensated. For me it was like paying 7 years of utilities in advance and paying next to nothing for the next 15 years. System life is expected to be 30 years, don't know if I will be able to renew my contract when the time comes.

The problem lies with corrupt politicians and their close alignment with public utility lobbyists, they are literally blotting out the sun for the people they are supposed to represent. The utilities now have custom crafted state legislation in place that makes rooftop solar too costly to consider due to the poor return on investment. They should at minimum pay you what you pay them for all the energy you produce.
Because corrupt state legislatures have poisoned the well when it comes to rooftop solar, we need federal laws to undo their political vandalism.
For solar to work and make an impact people need to be able to participate, not just commercial entities.

textDisplay: This whole video is built on a false assumption of: The only way to provide electricity is via huge renewable energy production systems and high voltage grids. The most environmentally, cheapest over all, and useful way to provide clean energy is to invest all of that time, effort, and most importantly the money into developing individual buildings that are electrically self-sufficient and off the grid. There are already lots of systems around the world which enable you to build solar and wind energy systems to power households, yet the problem is getting the governments to approve of their use as the sole source of power for the houses and to provide the financial support to convert the houses over.

textDisplay:
This is a great presentation. Has anybody thought of a decentralized electrical grid as a better solution to this problem? With the potential for consumers to produce their own electricity, the idea of having to clear more land and build more infrastructure out in the middle of nowhere sounds like a bad idea in the long term.

It would be more beneficial to communities to have the ability to generate their own power and create profit from it rather than pave the way for handouts to electric companies. Why not invest directly in the existing infrastructure of the American people and create jobs within our communities in one go?

textDisplay:
This is a super high 30,000-feet overview of Electrical Grid infrastructure. Because of that many things important issues were left out, Such as costs. The Economics of it is just as important as the cleanliness of it in order to make it feasable. Because transmitting a lot of energy through hundreds of miles its not only inefficient, it is wasteful. Not to mention the thousands of acres of land, Natural Habitats of many animals to be cleared to make space for these gigantic structures plus the land for the extra Solar and Wind power plants.
A Strata Group of Utah State Uni published a study on the "Footprint of Energy" where they found that Solar powerplant used 43.5 acres per MW Produced and wind farms took as much as 70.64 acres of land per MW produced.

Just my 2 cents.

A Strata Group of Utah State Uni published a study on the "Footprint of Energy" where they found that Solar powerplant used 43.5 acres per MW Produced and wind farms took as much as 70.64 acres of land per MW produced. 

Just my 2 cents.

textDisplay: Storage is not well represented here. There's a tradeoff between storage & many transmission lines. Storage can make a transmission line more efficient as most transmission lines are not fully utilized 24x7. By transmitting energy when the lines are underutilized, retaining energy in storage facilities & discharging these local storage units at times when the transmission lines are "full", we can reduce the incremental need for new transmission lines. Also, as others point out, the tradeoff between centralized & distributed generation is not well explained.
textOriginal: Storage is not well represented here. There's a tradeoff between storage & many transmission lines. Storage can make a transmission line more efficient as most transmission lines are not fully utilized 24x7. By transmitting energy when the lines are underutilized, retaining energy in storage facilities & discharging these local storage units at times when the transmission lines are "full", we can reduce the incremental need for new transmission lines. Also, as others point out, the tradeoff between centralized & distributed generation is not well explained.

Needing more transmission lines isn't a renewables problem. It's a people problem. We're increasing our energy consumption, and as your example pointed out right in the beginning, many of our transmission lines are already at, or near, their capacity.

The main difference with renewables is where they are built.

We'll need to move a few of course, but as a percentage, it's not that big of a deal. Most well just need to extend one end in a different direction, since the other end is going to somewhere that needs the electricity.

textDisplay:
What we really need are HTSC (high temperature super conducting) HVDC (high voltage direct current) power lines snaking around the country moving huge amounts of power around. These would be compact and in the ground because high temperature superconductors are awesome that way. This would have the added advantage of it is easy enough to build in redundant loops so that it would be a very resilient grid. When building at such scale to power the whole country, this is especially important. When getting to these high power levels, these sorts of superconductors can carry over 150x the power of copper and not need any cooling. While the issue is flipped to keeping the superconductors cold so they are operational, the energy loss as you scale to higher power levels grows slowly as in the cable with all of the insulation around it slowly gets a little thicker while the amount of power you can shove over the line grows dramatically and so quickly gets into the realm of economical when talking about huge amount of power. Especially with HVDC you don't have to worry about skinning and you only need two conductors in a coaxial configuration and the job is done. There is not even any external EMF in the coaxial configuration for the tin foil hat people to complain about. You could bring a sensitive meter along to prove this point.

Another elephant in the room is green energy storage. I think what we really need is to build a new 100 GW scale pumped hydro storage between the two Great Lakes of the largest height difference. The reason for pumped is we are already basically turning off Niagra Falls at night in a one way system, so the only way to scale further is to do pumped hydro storage between massive lakes, basically a giant gravity battery. The Bonneville Power Project could also be beefed up in the Northwest to be more of a peaker power system than a base-load while also basically eliminating the need for overflow channels when it is really rainy. I mean stuff chemical batteries everywhere gets to be a big problem, but we already have ways to make big solutions, granted we can move the power around to do it. At this battery buffers can alleviate the need for new power lines some by having a more continuous load over an existing power line as opposed to have it handle moment by moment load shifts and be designed for the peek power to flow through it, so chemical batteries are still quite useful even with massive scale gravity storage.
textOriginal:
What we really need are HTSC (high temperature super conducting) HVDC (high voltage direct current) power lines snaking around the country moving huge amounts of power around.  These would be compact and in the ground because high temperature superconductors are awesome that way.  This would have the added advantage of it is easy enough to build in redundant loops so that it would be a very resilient grid.  When building at such scale to power the whole country, this is especially important.  When getting to these high power levels, these sorts of superconductors can carry over 150x the power of copper and not need any cooling.  While the issue is flipped to keeping the superconductors cold so they are operational, the energy loss as you scale to higher power levels grows slowly as in the cable with all of the insulation around it slowly gets a little thicker while the amount of power you can shove over the line grows dramatically and so quickly gets into the realm of economical when talking about huge amount of power.  Especially with HVDC you don't have to worry about skinning and you only need two conductors in a coaxial configuration and the job is done.  There is not even any external EMF in the coaxial configuration for the tin foil hat people to complain about.  You could bring a sensitive meter along to prove this point.

Another elephant in the room is green energy storage.  I think what we really need is to build a new 100 GW scale pumped hydro storage between the two Great Lakes of the largest height difference.  The reason for pumped is we are already basically turning off Niagra Falls at night in a one way system, so the only way to scale further is to do pumped hydro storage between massive lakes, basically a giant gravity battery.  The Bonneville Power Project could also be beefed up in the Northwest to be more of a peaker power system than a base-load while also basically eliminating the need for overflow channels when it is really rainy.  I mean stuff chemical batteries everywhere gets to be a big problem, but we already have ways to make big solutions, granted we can move the power around to do it.  At this battery buffers can alleviate the need for new power lines some by having a more continuous load over an existing power line as opposed to have it handle moment by moment load shifts and be designed for the peek power to flow through it, so chemical batteries are still quite useful even with massive scale gravity storage.

textDisplay: The whole concept is wrong. Each dwelling needs to generate it's own power via fuel cells at the point of use rather than very wasteful transmission lines and lossy step-down transformers. If a home or business is not on the NG pipeline system, then propane tanks can be used plus wind and solar when available. NG pipelines have the added advantage of being buried and not subject to storm destruction --a constant problem in costal areas. The only byproduct of the fuel cell is water, a badly needed item in western drought stricken areas.

textDisplay:
Your video left out an important part: 60hz AC. For instance, Québec has its own 60hz, that is not sychronized with that of north east grid (which includes parts of Ontario). So any export of power from Québec has to go through an AC to DC to AC converters to ensure the 60hz that gets into the north east is synchonized to the north east grid's 60hz. When these "grid crossing" facilities are built, they are built with specific capacity (and in many cases one capacity in one direction and smaller capacity in order direction as a backup).
So if you want solar panels in Arizona to power a NYC subway train during the day and wind farm off Long Island to power Phoenix at night, you need to consider how many grid "borders" (requiring 60hz synchronization) will be needed and adjust the conversion capacity in each direction accordingly.
Québec built a DC power line from the LG2 area of its James Bay complex to Massachussets. There is still a conversion from AC to DC, but it is done at LG2 directly from turbine outputs, so this skips the turbine to high power AC transmission line stage. And it is converted to AC in Massachussets to the north each 60hz synch. The DC line is labeled at 450kv, but it is +450 and -450, so essentially 900kV and ony 2 wires, so less width in corridor is needed compared to 3 phase line.

When these "grid crossing" facilities are built, they are built with specific capacity (and in many cases one capacity in one direction and smaller capacity in order direction as a backup).

textDisplay:
Nuclear is green too. 4th generation plants can use the waste of older plants as new fuel, and we already have enough of that to keep the US going for a century. The material that’s left after that only needs to be stored 30 years rather than 30 thousand. 4th gen reactors are also unable to melt down, even if someone does the exact wrong thing like at Chernobyl. In terms of increased exposure to those living within 10 miles for a year, current reactors already cause less than coal, barely above the background radiation that happens everywhere, and 4th gen reactors would be even less. Small modular reactors are also possible with newer designs, allowing them to be buried anywhere, meaning that there’s no need to have high voltage lines crossing the nation.

The problem with wind & solar is that they are intermittent, producing most of their energy at times when less is needed. We’ll need huge battery banks to store the excess until it’s needed, and extracting the lithium necessary is already difficult. Pumped hydro is a good storage option, but we need to build the reservoirs to handle it, and climate change is already straining our freshwater resources , so we’ll need a lot more desalination and other water recovery plants as it is, which will use more electricity. I don’t think we’re getting out of our climate debt hole without using nuclear power.
textOriginal:
Nuclear is green too.  4th generation plants can use the waste of older plants as new fuel, and we already have enough of that to keep the US going for a century.  The material that’s left after that only needs to be stored 30 years rather than 30 thousand.  4th gen reactors are also unable to melt down, even if someone does the exact wrong thing like at Chernobyl.  In terms of increased exposure to those living within 10 miles for a year, current reactors already cause less than coal, barely above the background radiation that happens everywhere, and 4th gen reactors would be even less.  Small modular reactors are also possible with newer designs, allowing them to be buried anywhere, meaning that there’s no need to have high voltage lines crossing the nation.  

The problem with wind & solar is that they are intermittent, producing most of their energy at times when less is needed.  We’ll need huge battery banks to store the excess until it’s needed, and extracting the lithium necessary is already difficult.  Pumped hydro is a good storage option, but we need to build the reservoirs to handle it, and climate change is already straining our freshwater resources , so we’ll need a lot more desalination and other water recovery plants as it is, which will use more electricity.  I don’t think we’re getting out of our climate debt hole without using nuclear power.

The United States is falling behind with Russia, India and China who are developing this ahead of us.
We have to get away from this Boogeyman thing where the media is scaring the public and politicians.

It should be a standard policy to seek efficiencies that can lower monthly costs for American families.

textDisplay: As an electrical worker in Canada I can tell you the reasoning for HV is to make sure the voltage is usable once it arrives at the customer as conductors drop more voltage with current loads (heat) over long distances. High voltage allows for lower current loads, smaller conductors (material savings) and long distances. Governments should be building 750kv 3 Phase AC lines at a minimum as they have a massive 120v capacity as energy cannot be destroyed only transferred. One step above this is to build 1.1 M volt DC lines as there is no skin effect losses and less voltage drop in general as electrons travel one way but the trade off is power transformers and DC/AC rectifiers/inverters of that size are hard to build/transport. China already uses this technology. Currently 1.1 M volt DC lines go 4000kms between substations with current loads which honestly amazing. Most transmission lines of that voltage are 100-200FT in altitude and spaces vertically. What should happen is governments build renewable facility's in favorable remote areas and run those types of lines with multiple faculties reusing the same line with its capacity rating. Then Tie the lines into the nearest compatible substation using automated tie switches with alike system characteristics. The problem isn't the technology its the politics in the governments which is sad because they talk lots about climate change with no action when in reality they are just wasting more time while creating a more dire situation in the future. As mentioned in this video work takes time to complete. Even if work wont be energized immediately it should be ready for future use.

textDisplay:
People keep looking for singular and centralized solutions. The ideas presented in the video, are not wrong, just not the whole picture. Distributed resources and storage need to be part of the solution. I live in one of the cloudiest places in the US and yet, my rooftop solar offsets a large portion of my consumption. Every building has a roof, electricity produced on that roof is used locally, reducing stress on transmission infrastructure. Coupling that with storage at the building or substation level adds more stability.

The second part is improving how we use energy. Many older buildings leak conditioned air like a sieve because we still live like energy is free. Installing insulation and new windows in an old home can cut AC costs in half (I've seen it in my own homes). Next is applying some local-level automation. Simply managing my larger loads like AC, Dehumidifiers, and electric clothes dryer to reduce the times they run at the same time has reduced my peak demands significantly.

Grid level demand limiting has existed for quite some time. As far back as the late '80s, I remember folks having devices that allowed the power company to remotely turn off AC, water heaters, and the like for brief periods on a rolling basis. Where I work (100 plus buildings and our own combined heat and power plant) we have participated in programs that pay us to reduce consumption during "Peak Load Days."

It's not one solution, it's many solutions working together. We have to start looking at it holistically.
textOriginal:
People keep looking for singular and centralized solutions.  The ideas presented in the video, are not wrong, just not the whole picture.  Distributed resources and storage need to be part of the solution.  I live in one of the cloudiest places in the US and yet, my rooftop solar offsets a large portion of my consumption.  Every building has a roof, electricity produced on that roof is used locally, reducing stress on transmission infrastructure.  Coupling that with storage at the building or substation level adds more stability.

The second part is improving how we use energy.  Many older buildings leak conditioned air like a sieve because we still live like energy is free.  Installing insulation and new windows in an old home can cut AC costs in half (I've seen it in my own homes).   Next is applying some local-level automation.  Simply managing my larger loads like AC, Dehumidifiers, and electric clothes dryer to reduce the times they run at the same time has reduced my peak demands significantly.  

Grid level demand limiting has existed for quite some time.  As far back as the late '80s, I remember folks having devices that allowed the power company to remotely turn off AC, water heaters, and the like for brief periods on a rolling basis.  Where I work (100 plus buildings and our own combined heat and power plant) we have participated in programs that pay us to reduce consumption during "Peak Load Days." 

It's not one solution, it's many solutions working together.  We have to start looking at it holistically.

textDisplay: This may not be as big of an issue as you've made it out to be. There's a movement towards microgrids which may handle a lot more of this need. textDisplay: That's hilarious. Over here in The Netherlands we are getting rid of above-the-ground power wiring. We already have no above-the-ground wiring to houses, those are all underground, but now we're also getting rid of the above-the-ground high voltage transmission lines entirely. They're too maintenance-heavy and susceptible to failures during extreme weather events, and we don't even have hurricanes/typhoons.
textOriginal: That's hilarious. Over here in The Netherlands we are getting rid of above-the-ground power wiring. We already have no above-the-ground wiring to houses, those are all underground, but now we're also getting rid of the above-the-ground high voltage transmission lines entirely. They're too maintenance-heavy and susceptible to failures during extreme weather events, and we don't even have hurricanes/typhoons.

textDisplay: not just transmission lines, also levers of flexibility (of electricity production and demand) and storage solutions, since solar and wind power are intermittent. Electric mobility can play an important role with smart charging solutions (charging the battery when there is a high amount of renewable energy production, hence storing the green energy produced in excess) and vehicule-to-grid solutions that would offer the possibility to return a small part of the energy stored in the battery to the grid when needed (ie. as a paid service for professional fleets that are little used during peak consumption - usually at meal times).
textOriginal: not just transmission lines, also levers of flexibility (of electricity production and demand) and storage solutions, since solar and wind power are intermittent. Electric mobility can play an important role with smart charging solutions (charging the battery when there is a high amount of renewable energy production, hence storing the green energy produced in excess) and vehicule-to-grid solutions that would offer the possibility to return a small part of the energy stored in the battery to the grid when needed (ie. as a paid service for professional fleets that are little used during peak consumption - usually at meal times).

textDisplay: How is renewable energy working for energy? Last I heard they keep making gas and coal plants to make up for the downtime. California is also doing horribly. They have to pay Nevada to take their excess, then pay Nevada for power when the sun doesn't shine and when the wind doesn't blow. Or they turn on their gas power plants to make up the remainder. Come on people. Renewable isn't working (except for hydroelectric.  That stuff is actually pretty good). If it were working then why isn't every single country 1st world country using it? Not to mention the waste. In a few decades there will be more solar panel waste then there is plastic waste. And this waste is worse. They contain heavy metals like cadmium and lead that taint the soil and gets in the water supply of African and Indian people. That's where they dump the waste. Nuclear is the way. Look at France. They produce the cheapest, least destructive energy on the planet. A single nuclear power plant will be able to power New York City with ease for 80 years. Not to mention current reactors are physically unable to go critical. You can dump them in the ocean, have a magnitude 10 earthquake, a category 5 tornado, hurricane, whatever. They're unable to cause any harm whatsoever. "Well what about Chernobyl?" What about Chernobyl? Only 20 people died from Chernobyl. Radiation isn't as dangerous as the media depicted it to be. There is more background radiation in some high altitude American cities than there is in Chernobyl right now. And it's the same gamma radiation too

textDisplay: In addition to the plan they’re talking about here, in the urban planning/ architectural community there’s a lot of conversation about the strength in smaller, more wide spread implementation of renewable resources. Think row homes and bussinesses roofed in solar, small wind farm along high ways, ect. The advantage to this is because the energy is created where the need is there’s a lesser need for the transportation of the energy. This is important not only for the reasons in this video but because a lot of energy gets lost in the transfer from production to where it needs to go. The other benefit to this is that it is more resilient. If a storm comes and destroys the main energy plant for a city that’s hard to recover from. But with a grid with a larger amount of smaller inputs if a. Handful of them go out there’s still plenty to recover from. It’s the same idea as having multiple streams of income to provide financial stability.
textOriginal: In addition to the plan they’re talking about here, in the urban planning/ architectural community there’s a lot of conversation about the strength in smaller, more wide spread implementation of renewable resources. textDisplay:
As an engineer expert on the energy sector I hated this video.

The energy transition is much more than replacing one technology with another. We need to change the way we use energy and, thus, we will consume mainly electricity produced in our roofs, in our counties... The idea of transporting renewable electricity from Chicago to LA or viceversa it's ridiculous, do you have any idea of the power losses involved there? How weak the electric system would be with that scheme?

We won't be able to transport great amounts of electricity around the continent and our target must be to don't need it. The goal should be to gain autonomy and resilience locally, with the support of the neighbouring regions.
textOriginal:
As an engineer expert on the energy sector I hated this video. 

The energy transition is much more than replacing one technology with another. We need to change the way we use energy and, thus, we will consume mainly electricity produced in our roofs, in our counties... The idea of transporting renewable electricity from Chicago to LA or viceversa it's ridiculous, do you have any idea of the power losses involved there? How weak the electric system would be with that scheme?

We won't be able to transport great amounts of electricity around the continent and our target must be to don't need it. The goal should be to gain autonomy and resilience locally, with the support of the neighbouring regions.

textDisplay:
One problem with this theory is that it's very difficult to make very long high voltage lines, the losses on those lines become so big, it's not worth it. Thus, before anything gets built, we're going to have to rethink power distribution.
quick napkin math about what's said around 5:20 :
The distance between Arizona and Chicago is around 2697.261 km (~1676 miles).
Most transmission lines are limited to 190 km in length. (I googled it, but it seems a reasonable number)
2697.261 / 190 = 14,19
This means we would need power lines capable of being 14 times longer than the current maximum.
note: even if the value for max length differs, let's say 380 km, you still need 7 times the maximum.

textDisplay: The biggest problem with energy supply in the U.S. is the huge utility monopolies are heavily invested in fossil fuel and nuclear. They have a great deal of power ($$$$) in D.C. They use their power to get subsidies for unprofitable nuclear and restrict any legislation that enhances renewables, energy conservation and efficiency and modernization of the grid system. The utilities newest business model is to spend money lobbying or bribing legislators for nuclear subsidies (Ohio, NY, and Illinois) to keep nuclear open with the threat that they will go back to coal if the public doesn't hand them the loot. Nice campaign contributions mean more to politicians than a sensible energy policy. The sensible thing to do would be to shut down the nuclear and coal plants and invest in renewables, energy efficiency and storage and distribution systems. But if they did that the fossil fuel and nuclear plants would go immediately go from the assets side of the spreadsheet to the liability side and the utilities would go bankrupt. Propping up a failed energy or investment corporation to keep them from going belly up is crony capitalism. Big Biz and Big Gov are good at that. Sit back, folks, and watch the rest of the world outpace us economically because their industry will have cheaper, more efficient energy than ours.

textDisplay:
How “renewable” is it really if you’re digging up tons more of copper and aluminum ore, using GWhs of power to convert all that ore into more power lines & towers, tearing through large strips of land for new transmission right-of-ways, and spreading large wind turbines and solar farms all over the place (and battery storage, don’t forget that!).

Sending power long distances increases exposure to mother nature. Because generation isn’t where the load is, power system engineers have to implement RAS (remedial action schemes) to drop load when a critical path or assets are lost due to nature or human mistakes. We will be trading reliability for renewables, not sure if it’s worth all that extra money.

I live in a location where I’m not subject to (most) rotating blackouts because a large natural gas power plant is right down the street from me. If that power plant was removed, I know I would be added to a rotating blackout group. That’s a real world example of why having a power plant close to you is a good thing.

Like investing, putting all your energy source eggs in one basket is ripe for disaster. A more reasonable goal would be to choose to add just a percentage of renewable energy sources that balances these factors. When you only focus on one goal, sustainable energy, you subsequently cross off all the other important goals on that list. “Renewable” energy is subject to the laws of physics, economics, and Mother Nature just like any “non-renewable” energy resource. And “Conservation of energy shall not be violated!!”

Tl;dr 100% renewables prioritizes only the goal of zero carbon emissions, it throws other important goals like reliability out the window.

Trust me I’m an (electrical) engineer

textDisplay: Renewables do not need to be centralized gigawatt beasts, they can be built where the consumers are, or very close, so the baseload on transmission lines will lessen considerably. If you then spend money on storage, renewables become very dispatchable and you no longer need to provide both capacity and transmission for the usual morning and evening peaks. And again, that storage can actually live where the consumers are. All this modelling of demand, so that it can be guessed exactly 30 minutes into the future, so that gas plants can be quickly and dirtily lit up, to send hundreds of MW hundreds of kms away will soon be very outdated. Instead, it will be all about balancing out storage across whole continents, days in advance. But perhaps the good reason to upgrade that network is so that the PG&E can stop lighting california on fire all the time ;)

textDisplay: NOAA (the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration) spent 6 years examining this issue in detail.  They published the results of their studies, including solutions, in great detail, in the January 25, 2016 issue of Nature Climate Change.  The NOAA study rendered this VOX video completely obsolete in 2015.  AC power has too many inherent losses to solve this problem. NOAA concluded that we need underground high-voltage DC cables running along the right-of-ways of Interstate Highways and possibly some railway lines.  Cables adequate for doing this have already been developed by at least two very large companies capable of supplying the necessary HVDC underground cable.
textOriginal: NOAA (the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration) spent 6 years examining this issue in detail.  They published the results of their studies, including solutions, in great detail, in the January 25, 2016 issue of Nature Climate Change.  The NOAA study rendered this VOX video completely obsolete in 2015.  AC power has too many inherent losses to solve this problem. NOAA concluded that we need underground high-voltage DC cables running along the right-of-ways of Interstate Highways and possibly some railway lines.  Cables adequate for doing this have already been developed by at least two very large companies capable of supplying the necessary HVDC underground cable.

textDisplay:
More relatively expensive transmission lines may be the answer, but the expense of creating such transmission lines may not be as effective a solution as investing in community power generation everywhere. Community power generation has its own problems, but offering one expensive and politically problematic solution without placing it in the context of other solutions does a disservice to the watchers of this video.
There are many solutions, large and small to be pursued. An astute watcher might observe at 3:19 in the video that Rob Gramlich, speaking for Americans for a Clean Energy Grid, is sitting in front of an open ,highly inefficient fireplace and a large wall of windows that do not appear to be south facing. Are the windows at least double glazed? Hmmm....
Vox, you can do better than this.

textDisplay:
So you're in the wrong for several reasons:

-If you count the global footprint of transmission infrastructures, it makes you renewable project much less green , and irrelevant to solving the climate crisis. The longer the transmission lines, the more you loose energy on the way; as climate change progresses maintainance of those lines will become more complicated as well . What you need to do is moving people from the coast to the middle of America to reduce transmission losses. Don't make wind power farm, decentralise energy production, you won't have to build lines.

-electrify everything is irrelevant, you get too much conversion losses. To produce heat, use solar heat without converting it to electricity or use a break on your windmill.

Read more at solar low tech magazine

textDisplay: One of Vox’s best but this just supports the logic of nuclear. Not to mention solar panels and turbines have a shorter life span than a nuclear plant.

textDisplay: I am all for a zero carbon future, but I think you'll find it hard to replace natural gas heating hard to compete with as not only do heat pumps get less efficient as temps drop but right now electricity is still more expensive on a per kilowatt or kilowatt equivalent basis to natural gas. Also, while electrical transmission efficiency is high, so is pumping natural gas of which we can extract about 98-99% of the heat energy. Again, I am all for a zero carbon future, but natural gas isn't as bad as people think. Far better than coal, and yes I know it has still a huge environmental impact. Basically what I'm trying to say is we need to bring down the cost of electricity dramatically and also we need to improve the performance of heat pumps dramatically before switching away form natural gas. We need to remember that many home appliances use natural gas. Water heaters and stoves too. We need to improve it all before we see huge moves away from that.
textOriginal: I am all for a zero carbon future, but I think you'll find it hard to replace natural gas heating hard to compete with as not only do heat pumps get less efficient as temps drop but right now electricity is still more expensive on a per kilowatt or kilowatt equivalent basis to natural gas. textDisplay: Why not put the high voltage transmission lines underground? They could still be bare wire but run through concrete or other insulated pipe like ABS or PVC or something that has very high dielectric strength. They would be safer underground and resistant to weather or being damaged by falling trees, etc or causing damage if they were downed. And fewer people would oppose them because there aren't unsightly towers on land or the audible hum from the transmission lines.
textOriginal: Why not put the high voltage transmission lines underground? They could still be bare wire but run through concrete or other insulated pipe like ABS or PVC or something that has very high dielectric strength. They would be safer underground and resistant to weather or being damaged by falling trees, etc or causing damage if they were downed. And fewer people would oppose them because there aren't unsightly towers on land or the audible hum from the transmission lines.

textDisplay: This all seems sensible, but two questions nag me.  There are no comments on distributed generation, and on conservation.  It seems like this is just too trivial to consider, but is it really?  Do we really have to generate thousands of miles away from where the power will be used?  I don't know about industrial requirements, but I do think there are a ton of homes that could be refitted to conserve like 50 to 70% of their energy consumption, and then also fitted with solar to serve their energy needs.  I'm a bit further along this path than some, and I can tell you it is well within possibility for a house to be a net positive energy contributor to the grid.  Winter vs summer is more of an issue, but annually, for sure, and I believe even if I were to have 2 electric vehicles, I could supply them with whats generated on my house.  The models Princeton developed, do they not look at this possibility?
textOriginal: This all seems sensible, but two questions nag me.  There are no comments on distributed generation, and on conservation. textDisplay:
It is a complex topic. Because rooftop solar produces the electricity on location

So then, you want to model how much load is taken off the grid by rooftop solar. Since the watts go to the owner of the house or the neighbors. Retail building can have rooftop solar as well. I read some articles about Walmart doing this a few years back.

For industry. I think it makes more sense to move to where the energy is. For example. Move your aluminum factory to where the cheap energy is.

Base on Vox's diagram,. That would half the cost of electricity.

textDisplay:
I would've liked to hear how these hold up in natural disasters (other than fires). Because when I think Quebec and storms, I remember ice storms breaking their wire thingys by weight - but that was a long time ago, the year I was born. I'd assume things have improved.
It's also concerning when thinking about how far inland the last hurricane went. Hurricanes will be worse, tornadoes worse, thunderstorms worse, heatwaves worse, and so on. Could a system built on suspended wire keep up? Would a broken system devastate a country fully reliant on it (although that probably would be the same regardless of energy source)?
textOriginal:

textDisplay: What about the battery problem? Wind only works when the wind blows and sun only works when the sun shines. Water towers constantly store reservoirs during the day and night to have an enough water to meet demand during peak hours in the morning and evening, but wind and solar can only store their reserves in terribly inefficient lithium batteries (also super bad for the environment). We would either need to manufacture a multiplicity of the average demand for electricity (in order to meet peak hour demand), tell people to use less electricity, or have a breakthrough in battery technology. Nuclear electricity already have JIT capabilities, takes up less space and can be placed where there is no wind, little sun and no river.
textOriginal: What about the battery problem? Wind only works when the wind blows and sun only works when the sun shines. Water towers constantly store reservoirs during the day and night to have an enough water to meet demand during peak hours in the morning and evening, but wind and solar can only store their reserves in terribly inefficient lithium batteries (also super bad for the environment). We would either need to manufacture a multiplicity of the average demand for electricity (in order to meet peak hour demand), tell people to use less electricity, or have a breakthrough in battery technology. Nuclear electricity already have JIT capabilities, takes up less space and can be placed where there is no wind, little sun and no river.

textDisplay:
Those windmills are spinning backwards. Also, windmills are very inefficiently designed unfortunately, and in my opinion, "green/renewables" are incapable of meeting 100% of our power needs.
I'm not like Ronald Reagan, I don't want to take solar panels off the roofs of buildings, but powering houses is not even close to the total power needed including logistics.
The truth is that we need to be thinking about more than CO2, we need to be thinking about urban sprawl, traffic, etc.
Reducing the demand for fossil fuels is a great idea, but outright replacement of them is basically naive. Rethinking everything is not a good idea, when people hardly agree on anything.
Things like energy storage have already been solved, it's fossil fuels. Trying to reinvent the wheel is wasting peoples time, and distracting from the real problems.

textDisplay: Nice to see coverage on this topic for a broader audience. However, this episode hides 2 key factors: first, the grid does not solely exist out of power lines. Many (if not all) sustainable energy sources are variable in output (it is not always sunny or windy), which means you need large amounts of storage of energy to cope with peaks and falls. Secondly, the episode fails to mention there is an alternative to powerlines, which is building the power grid underground. While more expensive, it is a much more robust and future-proof alternative.
textOriginal: Nice to see coverage on this topic for a broader audience. However, this episode hides 2 key factors: first, the grid does not solely exist out of power lines. Many (if not all) sustainable energy sources are variable in output (it is not always sunny or windy), which means you need large amounts of storage of energy to cope with peaks and falls. Secondly, the episode fails to mention there is an alternative to powerlines, which is building the power grid underground. While more expensive, it is a much more robust and future-proof alternative.

textDisplay: This video mentions swapping wind farms to replace natural gas. The natural gas plants are built in conjunction with wind/solar. Wind/Solar REQUIRES a secondary power source for when the wind is blowing and sun isn't shining, and the most common one is natural gas. Wind/Solar might be a thousands times better than something like coal, but that doesn't make it the solution to the energy and climate issues. Suggesting it is is just looking at them on face value. Wind/Solar (and EV) aren't without major environmental impact themselves. The least impactful (and also GREEN) energy source we have right now is the one that no one wants to talk about and invest in: nuclear. And there have been major advancements in nuclear like mini reactors (sounds good for the power grid issues in this video), thorium reactors, meltdown-proof designs, and even nuclear recycling that cuts down the majority of waste and greatly reduces the half-life of any remaining waste.
